title.narrative: Scaling Investments 4 Resilience of East African Coffee Producers

description.narrative: To address the high costs of coffee production, poor governance in cooperatives, and decreasing coffee productivity and quality of coffee, we have supported small and medium scale coffee farmers in Tanzania, Uganda and Kenya to adopt good agricultural and climate smart practices. There was a marked improvement in coffee production across all the farmer archetypes in the three countries: Uganda, Kenya and Tanzania. In spite of lower coffee market prices over the period, farmer incomes improved due to improved yields and quality, as a result of the project's interventions. At the end of 2020, we have trained 22,663 farmers and workers in Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania to adopt good practices, financial management and building resilience to climate change. The project was able to provide access to basic financial services such as savings, credit and insurance to 3,300 beneficiaries in 300 Village Savings and Loan Associations (VSLAs) in Uganda and Tanzania. As at December 2020, at least 225,000 euros had been mobilized through these VLSAs. The project supported the farmers with access to (digital) information such as weather forecast data, technologies such as varietal conversion through top working, financial support and linkages to service providers of essential services such as climate insurance. The project supported over 3,840 women and girls to overcome typical barriers for women participation in the coffee value chain, through training on agronomic and marketing decision making, access to coffee production and marketing intelligence, representing the family in coffee meetings, managing a share of the coffee trees and allocation of a share of proceeds and business skills building and provision of opportunities to start income generating activities (e.g. fish farming, beekeeping, fruits and dairy production).

title.narrative: # of producers and miners (M/F/youth) that implement Good Practices

description.narrative: Farmers, workers and factory staff will be monitored.

comment.narrative: Farmers, workers and factory staff will be monitored.

There has been a very good adoption rate at 86 % of the agronomy, quality and top working trainings delivered. Quality aspects have been widely adopted at the factories and at the home processing units owned by the estate farmers. All the workers trained apply the newly acquired skills and are more conscious when handling coffee as observed. 23 of the trained youth have successfully converted coffee varieties for farmers in their cooperatives. There is a good adoption of good practices at the farms as farmers continue to access finances from the project partner (CMS) and other local banks. A financing model was developed linking Matungulu East Farmers to a local bank and an input supplier. The farmers through this initiative received all inputs required in the 2018/19 crop including labour. This has

title.narrative: # of producers and miners (M/F/youth) that implement Good Practices

description.narrative: Farmers, workers and factory staff will be supported

comment.narrative: Farmers, workers and factory staff will be supported

26% or 373 of the farmers trained in a period of 4 months have adopted various good practices disseminated to them through various trainings. Delivering trainings through the farmer field schools approach has increased the efficiency of the trainings as they are delivered in the farmers real environment and led by their own farmers. Support from the cooperative leaders and government officials have played a big role in enforcing the implementation of various trainings. Access to finance presents a big challenge in overcoming low adoption rates.

title.narrative: Farmers, workers, miners are trained in good practices

The design and implementation of a functional promoter farmer model implemented through a multi stakeholder approach enabled the project to surpass the initial project targets for the year 2018.

title.narrative: # of farmers/miners/workers (m/f) trained to adopt good practices

description.narrative: Farmers and workers will be trained.

comment.narrative: Farmers and workers will be trained.

There was a late start of the program activities in Tanzania due to change of government policies that affected the design of the program at the onset. However, following engagement with the government at various levels, the right environment was achieved paving way for the project implementation as from August 2018. The farmers and workers are undergoing a carefully designed program based on the national coffee curriculum of 12 different coffee related subjects with a single topic being covered each month. 4 Different topics have been covered so far. Upon the 1436 farmers covering the 12 subjects, they will graduate and a new lot of farmers recruited to be trained for another 12 months. Out of the 1,436 farmers reached so far, 247 are women, 50 are youth and 1139 are men. It is evident that women and youth participation in the coffee value chain in Tanzania is largely male dominated. The program has put in place measures in place to progressively overcome the barriers to participation.

title.narrative: # of farmers/miners/workers (m/f) trained to adopt good practices

comment.narrative: 54 % of the targeted farmers, workers and youth were reached with various trainings which composed of agronomic trainings, quality trainings for estate farm owners and factory workers and top working for the youth to enable them establish enterprises that will offer specialized services to farmers in need of varietal conversion. For the first time, there was emphasis on a wholesome approach that incorporated the farm workers as they implement trainings most of the time with the farm owners being supervisors. The trainings are designed on three levels each being handled every year. There is a fair participation in trainings between men and women as compared to the other East African Countries. By identifying economic activities in the coffee value chain targeting the youth such as provision of services, the youth are showing interest and are willing to participate. 671 Men participated in the trainings, 420 Women and 49 youth.
